questions.text: Study the given image and comment which of the following nerve will be least commonly involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The least commonly involved cranial nerve in the given condition is Cranial Nerve VIII (Vestibulocochlear Nerve). The jugular foramen is a key anatomical structure where Cranial Nerves IX (Glossopharyngeal), X (Vagus), and XI (Accessory) exit the skull. Lesions in this region frequently affect these three nerves, leading to jugular foramen syndrome (Vernet’s syndrome). However, Cranial Nerve VIII (Vestibulocochlear) does not pass through the jugular foramen. Instead, it exits the skull via the internal acoustic meatus, along with Cranial Nerve VII (Facial Nerve). Since CN VIII is anatomically separate from the jugular foramen, it is less commonly affected in such conditions. Incorrect Options: (B) Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal) Passes through the jugular foramen, making it commonly involved in lesions affecting this region. Damage leads to difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), loss of taste on the posterior third of the tongue, and loss of the gag reflex. (C) Cranial Nerve X (Vagus) Also exits via the jugular foramen, making it susceptible to involvement. Damage results in hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, loss of cough reflex, and autonomic dysfunction. (D) Cranial Nerve XI (Accessory) Passes through the jugular foramen and is commonly affected. Damage leads to weakness in the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, causing difficulty in head rotation and shoulder elevation.

questions.text: Spot Diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: Read the text below Sol : Odema of the uvula (Quinke's disease) Definitions: Quinke's disease is acute oedema of the uvula Peritonsilar Abscess (Quinsy): Commonest site: Upper pole of tonsils, usually unilateral.

questions.text: Metastasis of carcinoma buccal mucosa goes to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Patterns of spread of buccal mucosal carcinoma Early lesion is discrete and exophytic. As it enlarges, it penetrates the underlying muscle and eventually extends to skin. Peripheral growth occurs into gingivobuccal gutters and into gingiva and underlying bone. Lymphatic spread is first to Submandibular and subdigastric nodes. Distant metastasis is rare. Tumours of buccal mucosa “Tumors in this area have a propensity to spread locally and to metastasize to regional lymphatic’s”.

choices.text: Discharge after 2 days and follow up of the patient after 8 weeks

questions.text: After laparoscopic appendectomy, patient had fall from bed on her nose after which she had swelling in nose and slight difficulty in breathing. Next step in management :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The patient in the question had fall from bed following which there is a swelling in nose and slight difficulty in breathing. This patient has probably had septal haematoma which should be drained immediately under LA.

questions.text: Oral diaphragm is formed by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: BDC - 158 Sol : Mylohyoid is a flat triangular suprahyoid muscle : The two mylohyoids form the floor of mouth cavity. i.e. f orm the oral diaphragm. As far as other options are concerned – Genioglossus and myoglossus are muscles of tongue whereas Buccinator is a facial muscle.

questions.text: A 70 years old male presented with conductive deafness in left ear.His left tympanic membrane appears dull.On examination he has 3 cms enlarged cervical lymph node.On tympanometry,type B tympanogram is seen.Most likely diagnosis is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sol: NASOPHARYNGEAL CANCER SSx: neck mass (most common initial symptom, 70%), serous otitis media from eustachian tube obstruction (second most common presentation, 50%), nasal obstruction, cranial nerve palsies (abducens nerve most common cranial nerve palsy), recurrent epistaxis, trismus, headache Epstein-Barr Virus Association • Early Intracellular Antigen (EA): early intracellular antigen • Viral Capsule Antigen (VCA): late antigen, most specific immunological finding in nasopharyngeal cancer

questions.text: Study the given image and comment on ‘Hole’ Diameter:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) HEAD MIRROR • CONCAVE MIRROR • FOCAL LENGTH 25 CMS • DIAMETER 89 MM • HOLE D 19 MM

questions.text: Interpret the following audiogram
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) . Pure tone audiometry is used to measure the auditory threshold of an individual. The instrument used in the measurement of auditory threshold is known as the audiometer. If both AC and BC lines are in normal hearing If BC is normal, AC is poor --- conductive hearing loss ( AB bap is there) If both AC and BC are poor with AB gap present --- mixed hearing loss

questions.text: A 50 year old male patient presenting with hearing loss complaint was subjected to audiometry. His audiogram is shown below What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch Boiler's notch / Acoustic dip at 4K Hz, both for air and bone conduction. It is usually symmetrical on both sides. NIHL causes damage to hair cells, starting in the basal turn of cochlea. Outer hair cells affected before the inner hair cells.

questions.text: Identify the audiological investigation whose recordings are shown in the given picture
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • The auditory brainstem response (ABR) is an auditory evoked potential extracted from ongoing electrical activity in the brain and recorded via electrodes placed on the scalp. The measured recording is a series of six to seven vertex positive waves of which I through V are evaluated. These waves, labeled with Roman numerals in Jewett and Williston convention, occur in the first 10 milliseconds after onset of an auditory stimulus. The ABR is considered an exogenous response because it is dependent upon external factors.

questions.text: Identify the abnormality:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref: Read the text below Sol : Abnormal folds (STAHL'S BAR) 1.Abnormal folding of the ear is common. 2.A Stahl’s bar or third crus is a frequent finding. 3. In a small number of cases, the upper pole of the ear flops over and here the term ‘lop ear’ is used.

questions.text: Identify the landmark shown in given image :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Donaldson Line. The Donaldson Line is an imaginary landmark used in otologic surgery, particularly in posterior tympanotomy and labyrinthectomy, to identify the endolymphatic sac in relation to the posterior semicircular canal. It is drawn along the plane of the posterior semicircular canal and helps in locating the endolymphatic sac, which lies just inferior to this line in the posterior fossa dura. This landmark is critical during endolymphatic sac decompression surgery, a procedure used in Meniere’s disease, to ensure precise dissection and avoid damage to surrounding structures. Incorrect Options: A. Lateral Semicircular Canal The lateral (horizontal) semicircular canal is a bony structure seen as a prominent bulge in the medial wall of the middle ear (promontory). It is often used as a landmark in mastoid and middle ear surgeries, but it is not related to the Donaldson Line. B. Superior Semicircular Canal The superior semicircular canal is located in the petrous temporal bone and is involved in balance and spatial orientation. It is sometimes dehiscent (Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence Syndrome – SSCD), but it is not related to Donaldson’s Line. C. Facial Recess The facial recess is an important surgical landmark in posterior tympanotomy (cochlear implant surgeries). It is bounded by the facial nerve (medially), chorda tympani nerve (superiorly), and fossa incudis (laterally). While important in middle ear surgeries, it has no connection to the Donaldson Line.

questions.text: Identify the incision shown the given image ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Reference – Read the text below Sol : • Wilde's incision – This post-aural incision is used for a variant mastoiditis drainage, and was named after Sir William Wilde, an ENT surgeon in Dubli • Tympanomeatal flap is raised to expose the middle ear in endomeatal approach • Rosen’s incision is used in the endomeatal approach for stapedectomy • It is also used for exploratory tympanotomy.

questions.text: Identify the investigation:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tympanometry. Tympanometry is an objective test used to assess middle ear function and Eustachian tube dysfunction. It measures the compliance (mobility) of the tympanic membrane (eardrum) in response to changes in air pressure in the ear canal. The test generates a tympanogram, which helps diagnose conditions such as: Otitis media with effusion (showing a Type B curve) Eustachian tube dysfunction (showing a Type C curve) Otosclerosis or ossicular discontinuity (showing altered compliance) Tympanometry is non-invasive, quick, and widely used in both adults and children to assess middle ear pathology. Incorrect Options: (A) Politzer Test The Politzer test is a subjective test used to assess Eustachian tube patency by insufflating air into the nasal cavity while the patient swallows. It is obsolete and unreliable compared to tympanometry. (C) Vestibular Evoked Myogenic Potential (VEMP) VEMP is used to assess vestibular (balance) function, particularly the saccule and inferior vestibular nerve. It is not related to middle ear function, making it irrelevant to tympanometry. (D) Electrocochleography (ECochG) Electrocochleography is a test that records electrical activity from the cochlea and auditory nerve, primarily used to diagnose Meniere’s disease and cochlear hydrops. It does not assess middle ear function, making it an incorrect choice for this question.

choices.text: Right Conductive Deafness and Left Sensorineural Deafness.
Right Conductive Deafness and Left Conductive Deafness.
Right Sensorineural Deafness and Left Conductive Deafness
Right Sensorineural Deafness and Left Sensorineural Deafness

questions.text: Comment on the diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Reference – Read the text below Sol : Rinne Test: Air conduction (AC) of the ear is compared with its bone conduction (BC) Positive Rinne Test: AC > BC Seen in normal persons or those having sensory-neural deafness Negative Rinne Test: BC > AC Seen in conductive deafness Important point: A negative Rinne indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 15-20 db. False negative Rinne test is seen in severe unilateral sensory-neural hearing loss

questions.text: Study the given image and comment on the diagnosis :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref:Read the text below Sol: • Michel aplasia, also known as complete labyrinthine aplasia (CLA), is a congenital abnormality of the inner ear. • It is characterized by the bilateral absence of differentiated inner ear structures and results in complete deafness (anacusis)

questions.text: Study the given instrument,it is being used for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It is transistorized, battery operated portable device. Its vibrating disc is held against the soft tissues of the neck and a low pitched sound is produced in the Hypopharynx which is further modulated into speech by the tongue, lip, teeth and palate.

questions.text: A 2 year old child presents to emergency with fever and respiratory distress. He has drooling of saliva and her mother told he has been refusing feeds since yesterday. Xray soft tissue neck lateral view is shown in picture. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Retropharyngeal Space - Between the buccopharyngeal fascia covering the pharyngeal constrictor & the prevertebral fascia * Extends from base of skull to bifurcation of trachea * Divided by a fibrous raphe into 2 (spaces of Gilette) * Abscess causes U/L bulge on post pharyngeal wall Acute retropharyngeal abscess - Commonly seen in children < 3yrs * Results of suppuration of retropharyngeal LN * In adults - from penetrating injury of post. pharyngeal wall C/F : * Dysphagia & difficulty in breathing (prominent symp) * Stridor & croupy cough * Torticollis * Bulge in post. Pharyngeal wall (usually seen on one side of midline) Xray STN lat. view - widening of prevertebral shadow T/t - I & D without GA, antibiotics

questions.text: 16 years old promila presents with pain over the cheek . Patient also complains of purulent nasal discharge. Examination Reveals oedema of lower eyelids and purulent discharge in middle meatus. Involvement of which of the following para-nasal sinus is suspected.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is a case of maxillary sinusitis with pre septal cellulitis. However, ethmoid sinusitis is most likely to cause orbital infection.

questions.text: A 37 year old patient with Diabetic Ketoacidosis is admitted in ICU. On ENT examination, he is found to be having blackish mass in the nose and necrosis of skin of external nose. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) . Mucormycosis (rhinocerebral phycomycosis): 1. Is an aggressive opportunistic fungal infection 2. Organism: Order: Mucor/Rhizopus oryzae 3. Predisposing factors: immunosuppressed patients, uncontrolled young diabetics

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Reduction Rhinoplasty Reduction rhinoplasty is a surgical procedure performed to reshape and reduce the size of the nose, particularly in cases of hump nose or nasal dorsum prominence. This surgery typically involves: Dorsal hump reduction (removal of bone or cartilage from the nasal bridge). Osteotomies to narrow the nasal bones. Tip refinement to achieve a more balanced nasal structure. It is commonly performed for cosmetic or functional reasons. Incorrect Options: (A) Submucous Resection (SMR) SMR is a functional procedure aimed at correcting a deviated nasal septum by removing a portion of the cartilage and bone. It is not primarily intended for external nasal shape modification. (B) Augmentation Rhinoplasty Augmentation rhinoplasty is the opposite of reduction rhinoplasty. It is performed to increase the nasal height or projection, often using cartilage grafts (e.g., from the rib, iliac crest, or ear). It is commonly done in saddle nose deformity. (D) Le Fort I Fracture Reduction Le Fort I fracture involves a horizontal fracture of the maxilla. Its treatment focuses on repositioning and stabilizing the fractured maxilla using plating and fixation, not nasal reshaping.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: Read the text below Sol:

questions.text: Study the given image and comment on the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: Read the text below Sol : Eagle’s syndrome • Bilateral ossification of stylohyoid ligaments • Eagle’s syndrome is characterised by pain in tonsillar fossa and upper neck. • Pain radiates of ipsilateral ear. • There is aggravation of pain on swallowing. • It is caused by calcification of stylohyoid ligament / elongation of styloid process.

questions.text: A 33 year old female patient has suddenly developed Aphonia. Her Laryngeal endoscopy picture shows immobile cords as shown in the picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of auditory brainstem implant?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A patient of left sided Meniere’s disease does not respond to conventional medical treatment. His episodes are becoming more frequent and he has developed severe sensorineural hearing loss on left side. Identify the treatment being rendered to patient in given picture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Microwick-assisted transtympanic Gentamicin injection. In patients with intractable Meniere’s disease who do not respond to medical treatment and have developed severe sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), intratympanic Gentamicin injection is a widely used treatment option. Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that selectively damages vestibular hair cells while sparing the cochlear function in some cases. It is injected transtympanically (through the tympanic membrane) using a microwick, which allows gradual diffusion into the inner ear. The goal is to reduce vertigo episodes by ablating vestibular function while minimizing systemic side effects. Since the patient already has severe SNHL, the risk of further hearing loss is not a concern, making this a viable treatment choice. Incorrect Options: A. Cody Tack Procedure Cody Tack procedure is not a recognized treatment for Meniere’s disease. It seems to be a misnomer or a mix-up with other vestibular procedures like endolymphatic sac decompression or vestibular neurectomy. Not relevant in the given scenario. B. Particle Repositioning Maneuver Particle repositioning maneuvers (e.g., Epley, Semont maneuvers) are used to treat Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV), a condition caused by displaced otoconia in the semicircular canals. Meniere’s disease is not caused by canalithiasis, so these maneuvers are not effective. D. Middle Ear Ventilation Tube Middle ear ventilation tubes (grommets) are used primarily in otitis media with effusion (OME) or Eustachian tube dysfunction, not in Meniere’s disease. Although some studies have suggested that ventilation tubes may help with pressure regulation in early Meniere’s, they are not the treatment of choice in advanced cases with severe SNHL.

questions.text: Which membrane separates Scala Vestibuli and Scala Media?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Basilar membrane separates Scala Media and Scala Tympani Reissner’s membrane separates Scala Vestibuli and Scala media Tectorial membrane covers Organ of corti

choices.text: It has surgically implantable titanium fixture
it transmits sound directly to cochlea through the bone conduction using the principle of osseointegration
It is indicated in patients with External Auditory canal atresia
It is not indicated in patients with chronic discharging ear with hearing loss

questions.text: All of the following are true about bone anchored hearing aid except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) . BAHA- bone anchored hearing aid will be given to hearing impaired individuals where conventional hearing aids can not be given like in bilateral Anotia, EAC atresia, discharging ear, EAC stenosis. Its a specialised device which is surgically fitted partly on to mastoid bone. it transmits sound directly to cochlea through the bone conduction using the principle of osseointegration

questions.text: Identify the prosthesis given in the picture used in treatment of serous otitis media
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A newborn baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing Direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings. Which of the following stridor is seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Inspiratory stridor The above clinical scenario along with the laryngoscopy Image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Inspiratory stridor is seen in laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of spontaneous nasal bleeding. There is no history of trauma or fall. He gives a history of unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken, which is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Antral sign The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the antral sign or Holman-Miller sign. The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma commonly arising from the sphenopalatine foramen.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion The given clinical scenario along with type B tympanometry curve is suggestive of serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion would be the most appropriate management.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Laryngocele The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling are suggestive of laryngocele.

questions.text: Given below is the endoscopic view of the right nasal cavity. Identify the marked structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Inferior Turbinate The marked structure is the lowermost projection in the lateral wall of the nose, the inferior turbinate. The middle turbinate is seen as superior to it. The lateral wall of the nose contains three or sometimes four projections of variable size namely superior, middle, and inferior turbinates along with a corresponding meatus under each turbinate. The inferior turbinate is the largest turbinate and occupies the lower third of the lateral nasal wall. It is a separate bone. Middle and superior turbínates are ethmoturbinal, part of the ethmoid bone.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with multiple nodules in the nasal mucosa. Biopsy from the nodules revealed the presence of Miculikz cells and Russell bodies. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rhinoscleroma The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings showing Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristic of rhinoscleroma. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli. Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by plasma cells. Histology also shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes and eosinophils

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Quinsy The given clinical scenario describes a child with fever, otalgia, trismus, and odynophagia with a normal external facial examination. The oral cavity shows congested and edematous tonsil and tonsillar pillars with edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. These findings are highly suggestive of quinsy (peritonsillar abscess). It is the collection of pus in the peritonsillar space between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. Both aerobic and anaerobic organisms are seen.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fossa of Rosenmuller The image shown is the endoscopic view of lateral wall of the nasophary the fossa of Rosenmuller. The nasopharynx is present above the soft palate and is made up of the ro lateral walls.

questions.text: The following instrument is useful in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anterior rhinoscopy The above is a thudicum nasal speculum. It is used to part the ala so as to visualize the anterior part of the nasal cavity. Structures visualized on Anterior rhinoscopy are: Septum, Lateral wall (Middle and inferior turbinate), Floor Posterior rhinoscopy is done using a St. Clair Thompson's Posterior rhinoscopy mirror through the oral cavity.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is this sign called?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Schwartze sign The otoscopic picture of both the tympanic membranes shows the Schwartze sign. This finding along with the history of bilateral conductive deafness is seen in active otosclerosis.

questions.text: A child with protruding ears as shown is brought to the OPD by his worried parents. They opt for surgical correction of the defect due to cosmetic reasons. After what age would you proceed with the surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 6 years Protruding ears or bat ears can be corrected anytime after 6 years of age if cosmetic appearance demands. This is due to the fact that the pinna is completely developed and achieves adult configuration by the age of 6 years.

choices.text: Reduction of the fracture of nasal bone
Punching out bone in DCR procedure

questions.text: What is the main use of the instrument seen in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Reduction of the fracture of nasal bone The instrument seen in the image is Walsham forceps. It is is mainly used to reduce nasal bone fracture.

questions.text: The test shown in the image is used to detect the abnormality of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nasal valve The test shown in the image is the Cottle test. It is used to detect abnormalities of the vestibular component of the nasal valve. In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve. The nasal airway improves as the nasal valve opens upon performing this maneuver. This helps us in finding the site of obstruction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman came with complaints of progressive hearing loss and tinnitus for a few weeks. Pure tone audiometry was done as shown below. Which of the following phenomenon is seen in the above patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Paracusis willisii The clinical scenario of pregnant women presenting with progressive hearing loss, tinnitus, and pure tone audiometry showing Carhart’s notch is suggestive of Otosclerosis. Paracusis willisii is seen in patients with stapedial otosclerosis. An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. The louder voice is better transmitted through the fixed stapes. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis willisii.

choices.text: Males are affected more commonly than females

questions.text: A 38-year-old housewife presents with facial weakness on the right side, difficulty in closing the right eye, and loss of taste sensation. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Males are affected more commonly than females Bell’s palsy affects both males and females equally. It is an acute onset idiopathic ipsilateral LMN facial nerve palsy. Most of the evidence supports the viral etiology due to herpes simplex, herpes zoster, or the Epstein-Barr virus.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with hoarseness and a low-pitched voice. She is a singer and a known smoker. Her laryngoscopy findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Reinke's edema The laryngoscopy findings show diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds suggestive of Reinke's edema.

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of a sudden loss of taste and hearing loss. He also says he is unable to close one eye and tears do not stop flowing. On examination, there are lesions In the ear as shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ramsay Hunt syndrome Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also known as herpes zoster oticus, is a late complication of varicella-zoster virus infection that results in inflammation of the geniculate ganglion of cranial nerve VII. Ramsay Hunt is a clinical diagnosis and classically is described as a triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, otalgia, and vesicles near the ear and auditory canal. Diagnosis is often missed or delayed, which can lead to an increased incidence of long-term complications. The condition is self-limiting, but treatment is targeted at decreasing the total duration of the illness as well as providing analgesia and preventing the complications that can occur.

questions.text: A patient undergoes indirect laryngoscopy as a part of his routine ENT examination. The laryngoscopy image is given below. Identify the structure marked as A:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pyriform fossa The pyriform sinus (also piriform recess, piriform sinus, piriform fossa, or smuggler's fossa) is a small recess on either side of the laryngeal inlet. It is bounded medially by the aryepiglottic fold, and laterally by the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane. The fossae are involved in speech

questions.text: Which of the following x-ray view is shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Caldwell's view The Caldwell view is a caudally angled radiograph, with its posteroanterior projection allowing for minimal radiation to the orbits. This view aids in visualizing the paranasal sinuses, especially the frontal sinus. It can help to assess inflammatory conditions such as sinusitis and secondary osteomyelitis, and sinus polyps or cysts.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient presents with hearing loss and tinnitus for the last several years. The hearing loss has been worsening while the tinnitus is pulsatile. Otoscopy reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Glomus tumor This clinical scenario with progressive hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus for several weeks, and a red mass behind an intact tympanic membrane are suggestive of glomus tumor.
